title: Acute Ischemic Stroke
icd10: I63.50 (Cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of unspecified cerebral artery)
I63.30 (Cerebral infarction due to thrombosis of unspecified cerebral artery)
I63.40 (Cerebral infarction due to embolism of unspecified cerebral artery)
scope: ** Acute ischemic stroke in adults — covers initial stabilization, thrombolytic therapy (IV alteplase/tenecteplase), endovascular thrombectomy criteria, blood pressure management, stroke etiology workup, secondary prevention initiation, and early rehabilitation. Excludes hemorrhagic stroke (see Intracerebral Hemorrhage template), transient ischemic attack (see TIA template), pediatric stroke, and chronic post-stroke management.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia mimics stroke; must rule out before tPA
Electrolyte abnormalities, renal function for contrast/medication dosing
Heparin use; elevated aPTT contraindicates tPA
Acute MI can cause cardioembolic stroke; stress cardiomyopathy
Potential need for blood products, surgical intervention
Baseline for statin therapy; cardiovascular risk assessment

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Liver disease affects anticoagulation, medication metabolism
Thyroid dysfunction as cardiovascular risk factor; atrial fibrillation workup
Affects treatment decisions (tPA risk-benefit), imaging choices
Intoxication as stroke mimic; affects exam reliability
Hypomagnesemia associated with arrhythmia, vascular risk
Refeeding risk if malnourished; metabolic panel

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Hypercoagulable panel (protein C, protein S, antithrombin III, Factor V Leiden, prothrombin gene mutation)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Young stroke (<50), cryptogenic stroke, venous thrombosis history

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Antiphospholipid antibody panel (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, β2-glycoprotein I)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Young stroke, recurrent stroke, systemic lupus
Elevated homocysteine as independent stroke risk factor
Sickle cell disease (young patients, African descent)
DIC, paradoxical embolism through PFO, cancer-associated

Essential/First-line.target: Exclude hemorrhage; may show early ischemic changes (loss of gray-white differentiation, sulcal effacement)
Large vessel occlusion (LVO) for thrombectomy; carotid/vertebral stenosis or dissection
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate), eGFR <30 (benefit outweighs risk in acute setting)

Essential/First-line.timing: With CTA if extended window (6-24h) or wake-up stroke
Essential/First-line.target: Ischemic penumbra (mismatch between core infarct and hypoperfused tissue); target mismatch ratio >1.8
Acute ischemic infarct (restricted diffusion); stroke location and extent; ASPECTS scoring
Atrial fibrillation, acute MI, LVH, ST changes

Extended.target: LV thrombus, PFO, valvular disease, cardiomyopathy, akinetic segments

Extended.timing: Within 48-72h if TTE nondiagnostic or cryptogenic stroke
Extended.target: PFO with right-to-left shunt, atrial septal aneurysm, left atrial appendage thrombus, aortic arch atheroma
Intracranial stenosis, vasospasm, microembolic signals, right-to-left shunt (bubble study)

Extended.item: Extended cardiac monitoring (Holter 30-day or implantable loop recorder)
Extended.timing: Arrange before discharge if cryptogenic stroke
Extended.target: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (detected in 12-30% with prolonged monitoring)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If vasculitis, dissection, or Moyamoya suspected
Rare/Specialized.target: Beading pattern (vasculitis), intimal flap (dissection), Moyamoya collaterals
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Contrast allergy, severe renal impairment, coagulopathy

Rare/Specialized.timing: If intracranial stenosis or vasculitis suspected
Rare/Specialized.target: Vessel wall enhancement (vasculitis, unstable plaque), dissection

Rare/Specialized.timing: If cardiomyopathy or cardiac mass suspected

dosing.instructions: 0.9 mg/kg IV (max 90 mg); 10% as bolus over 1 min, remaining 90% infused over 60 min. Door-to-needle target <45 min

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: >4.5h from last known well (relative 3-4.5h window with additional exclusions); BP >185/110 despite treatment; platelets <100K; INR >1.7; active bleeding; recent surgery <14 days; recent stroke <3 months; intracranial hemorrhage history
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Neuro checks q15min during infusion, q30min x 6h, then q1h x 18h; BP q15min x 2h, q30min x 6h, then q1h; hold anticoagulants/antiplatelets 24h

dosing.instructions: 0.25 mg/kg IV single bolus (max 25 mg); preferred if LVO planned for thrombectomy
For LVO (ICA, M1, M1-M2 junction, basilar); within 24h if eligible per DAWN/DEFUSE-3 criteria. 0-6h: NIHSS ≥6, ASPECTS ≥6. 6-24h: clinical-core mismatch on perfusion imaging

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Large established infarct core (ASPECTS <6 in 0-6h window); no LVO; poor premorbid function (mRS >2 relative); life expectancy <6 months
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Continuous monitoring in neuro-ICU post-procedure; groin check; BP per post-thrombectomy protocol

dosing.instructions: 325 mg PO/PR load (give within 24-48h of onset); if tPA given, wait 24h and obtain CT before starting. Maintenance: 81-325 mg daily

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active GI bleed, true aspirin allergy, within 24h of tPA (wait for post-tPA CT)

Acute/Emergent.item: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Labetalol IV (CPT 96374)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Labetalol IV (CPT 96374) 10-20 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV over 1-2 min; may repeat once; target BP <185/110 before tPA
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Labetalol IV (CPT 96374) 10-20 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Heart block (2nd/3rd degree), severe bradycardia, decompensated HF, asthma/severe COPD

Acute/Emergent.item: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Nicardipine IV (CPT 96365)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Nicardipine IV (CPT 96365) 5 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/h IV infusion; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h; target BP <185/110
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Nicardipine IV (CPT 96365) 5 mg/h IV

Acute/Emergent.item: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Clevidipine IV (CPT 96365)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Clevidipine IV (CPT 96365) 1-2 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg/h IV; titrate by doubling q90sec initially; max 32 mg/h
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure management PRE-tPA: Clevidipine IV (CPT 96365) 1-2 mg/h IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Soy/egg allergy, severe lipid disorders, defective lipid metabolism

dosing.instructions: Target BP <180/105 x 24h post-tPA; use nicardipine or labetalol drip as above
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure management POST-tPA (24h) - IV - see dosing

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Neuro checks with each BP check; hold if SBP <100

dosing.instructions: Allow BP up to 220/120; treat only if >220/120 or end-organ damage (ACS, aortic dissection, hypertensive encephalopathy). Lower by 15% in first 24h
Isotonic fluids; avoid dextrose-containing solutions (hyperglycemia worsens outcomes); avoid hypotonic solutions (cerebral edema risk)
dosing.orderSentence: IV normal saline - IV - see dosing

dosing.instructions: Only if SpO2 <94%; nasal cannula or mask as needed

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: SpO2 target ≥94%; avoid routine supplemental O2 if normoxic

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/PR q6h; max 4g/day (2g if hepatic impairment)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Temperature q4h; LFTs if prolonged use

dosing.instructions: Sliding scale or insulin drip for persistent hyperglycemia; target glucose 140-180 mg/dL; avoid hypoglycemia (<60 mg/dL)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BG q1h if drip; q6h if sliding scale

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN
40 mg SC daily; start within 24-48h if not receiving therapeutic anticoagulation; after post-tPA imaging clears hemorrhage

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active bleeding, platelets <50K, CrCl <30 (use UFH 5000u SC q8-12h)

dosing.instructions: 5000 units SC q8-12h
Apply to both legs immediately on admission; use in addition to or instead of pharmacologic prophylaxis

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Acute DVT, severe peripheral vascular disease

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: C. difficile risk with prolonged use

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT): Aspirin + Clopidogrel 81 mg -

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg + Clopidogrel 75 mg daily x 21 days (minor stroke NIHSS ≤3 or high-risk TIA ABCD2 ≥4); then single antiplatelet long-term. Load clopidogrel 300 mg if not previously on it
dosing.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT): Aspirin + Clopidogrel 81 mg -

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Major stroke (NIHSS >3), high bleeding risk, planned surgery

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy: Aspirin + Ticagrelor 81 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg daily + Ticagrelor 90 mg BID x 30 days (THALES trial: minor stroke NIHSS ≤5); then single antiplatelet
dosing.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy: Aspirin + Ticagrelor 81 mg PO

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Intracranial stenosis (may use), high bleeding risk, hepatic impairment

dosing.instructions: Bolus 60-80 units/kg (max 5000u); infusion 12-18 units/kg/h; target aPTT 1.5-2.5x control. Use for: cardiac source with high re-embolization risk, arterial dissection, crescendo TIA, free-floating thrombus

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Large infarct (hemorrhagic transformation risk), uncontrolled BP, within 24h of tPA
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: aPTT q6h until stable, then q12-24h; platelets q3 days; neuro checks

dosing.instructions: For malignant MCA syndrome with >50% MCA territory infarct, age <60 preferred; within 48h of onset; reduces mortality from 70-80% to ~20%

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Age >60 (relative — DESTINY II showed benefit up to age 80 but with higher disability); bilateral infarcts; hemorrhagic transformation
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-operative neuro checks, ICP monitoring, wound care

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus for acute herniation; 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h maintenance

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Serum osmolality (hold if >320 mOsm/kg), osmolar gap, renal function, I/O

dosing.instructions: 30 mL IV bolus via central line over 10-20 min for acute herniation

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Serum sodium (target 145-155 mEq/L), osmolality, central line integrity

dosing.instructions: 150-500 mL IV bolus or continuous infusion 0.5-1 mL/kg/h; target Na 145-155
80 mg PO daily (high-intensity); start within 24-48h regardless of baseline LDL

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.monitoring: LFTs at 12 weeks then annually; lipid panel at 4-12 weeks; CK if myalgia

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mg PO daily (high-intensity alternative)

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Active liver disease, pregnancy, CrCl <30 for 40mg

dosing.instructions: 5 mg PO BID (2.5 mg BID if ≥2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60kg, Cr ≥1.5); start 4-14 days post-stroke for AF (timing based on infarct size). Preferred DOAC per guidelines
20 mg PO daily with evening meal (15 mg daily if CrCl 15-50); start 4-14 days post-stroke for AF

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Renal function q6-12 months; bleeding signs

dosing.instructions: 150 mg PO BID (75 mg BID if CrCl 15-30); start 4-14 days post-stroke for AF

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Renal function q6-12 months; bleeding signs; GI side effects

dosing.instructions: 5 mg PO daily initial (2-3 mg if elderly, low weight, or interacting drugs); target INR 2.0-3.0 for AF; 2.5-3.5 for mechanical valve. Bridge with heparin

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: INR daily until stable, then weekly, then monthly; diet counseling (vitamin K)

dosing.instructions: Start 5-10 mg PO daily; titrate to 20-40 mg daily; target BP <130/80 after acute phase

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Cr and K+ at 1-2 weeks after initiation; BP

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily; max 10 mg daily
Start 50 mg PO daily; max 100 mg daily
Start 25 mg PO daily; titrate to 200 mg daily
10 mg PO daily; add if LDL not at goal on max statin
140 mg SC q2 weeks or 420 mg SC monthly; if LDL not at goal on max statin + ezetimibe

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Lipid panel q4-12 weeks; injection site reactions

Referrals & Consults.indication: All acute stroke presentations; tPA decision; stroke workup
Large vessel occlusion on CTA for thrombectomy
Malignant MCA edema, posterior fossa stroke with hydrocephalus, hemorrhagic transformation requiring intervention
Newly detected atrial fibrillation, acute MI, cardiomyopathy, PFO evaluation
Symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% (NASCET) for endarterectomy; ideally within 2 weeks
Dysphagia screening before any PO intake; aphasia evaluation; cognitive-communication assessment
Early mobilization within 24-48h (AVERT trial: avoid very early aggressive mobilization <24h); gait and balance training
ADL assessment, upper extremity function, adaptive equipment, cognitive rehabilitation
Determine rehabilitation disposition (inpatient rehab, SNF, home health, outpatient)
Discharge planning, insurance, DME, caregiver support, advance directives
Dysphagia diet recommendations, cardiovascular risk diet (Mediterranean, DASH)
Large territory stroke with poor prognosis, goals of care discussion

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new symptoms: sudden weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty, severe headache, loss of balance
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology (minimum 2 weeks; state-specific laws apply)
Take all medications as prescribed; do NOT stop antiplatelet or anticoagulant without medical advice
Swallowing precautions per SLP recommendations (sit upright 90° for meals, specific diet texture)
Fall prevention: clear pathways, use assistive devices, adequate lighting, non-slip surfaces
Blood pressure monitoring at home (target <130/80 per physician guidance)
Stroke signs education for patient and family: F.A.S.T. (Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911)
Medication list: carry updated list including all prescriptions, OTC, and supplements
Follow-up appointment with neurology in 1-2 weeks; primary care in 2-4 weeks
Report any bleeding (bruising, blood in stool/urine, gum bleeding) if on anticoagulation

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Sodium restriction <2.3 g/day (ideally <1.5 g if hypertensive)
Regular aerobic exercise: 40 min moderate intensity, 3-4 days/week (after medical clearance)
Alcohol limitation: ≤1 drink/day women, ≤2 drinks/day men; cessation if heavy use
Obstructive sleep apnea screening (Berlin questionnaire or STOP-BANG); CPAP if diagnosed
Stress management and emotional support (depression common post-stroke)

differential.features: Glucose <60; symptoms resolve with dextrose; diaphoresis, tremor
Witnessed seizure, post-ictal confusion, resolves within 24h; may have known epilepsy
Headache history, aura preceding deficit, gradual onset ("marching"), younger patient, family history
CT shows hemorrhage; more severe headache, rapid progression, vomiting
Subacute onset over days-weeks, progressive symptoms, headache worse in morning
History of trauma or anticoagulation; subacute confusion, headache, fluctuating symptoms
Severely elevated BP, headache, confusion, visual changes, seizures; typically posterior involvement
differential.tests: MRI FLAIR (posterior white matter edema), BP >220/120
MRI with contrast, LP, blood cultures

differential.features: Non-anatomic distribution, Hoover sign positive, give-way weakness, distractible exam findings
Isolated vertigo, positive HINTS peripheral pattern, no other neurologic deficits
Young patient, prior episodes, symptoms disseminated in space and time
Bilateral, non-focal exam (usually); abnormal metabolic labs; confusion predominates

evidence.source: [AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines (Powers et al.)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31662037/); [NINDS trial (NEJM 1995)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7477192/); [ECASS III (Hacke et al. NEJM 2008)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18815396/)

evidence.recommendation: Tenecteplase non-inferior to alteplase for LVO
evidence.source: [AcT trial (Menon et al. Lancet 2022)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35779553/); EXTEND-IA TNK
[MR CLEAN (Berkhemer et al. NEJM 2015)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25517348/), ESCAPE, EXTEND-IA, SWIFT-PRIME, REVASCAT
[DAWN trial (Nogueira et al. NEJM 2018)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29129157/); [DEFUSE-3 (Albers et al. NEJM 2018)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29364767/)

evidence.recommendation: DAPT 21 days for minor stroke/high-risk TIA
evidence.source: [CHANCE trial (Wang et al. NEJM 2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23803136/); POINT trial

evidence.recommendation: Aspirin + ticagrelor 30 days for minor stroke

evidence.source: AVERT trial (very early <24h aggressive mobilization harmful)

evidence.recommendation: Extended cardiac monitoring for cryptogenic stroke
PFO closure for cryptogenic stroke age 18-60
Permissive hypertension (up to 220/120 if no tPA)

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h (post-tPA: q15min x 2h, q30min x 6h, q1h x 16h), then q4h x 48h, then q shift
monitoring.action: If NIHSS increases ≥4 points: STAT CT head, call stroke team; consider hemorrhagic transformation, re-occlusion, or new stroke

monitoring.frequency: Post-tPA: q15min x 2h, q30min x 6h, q1h x 16h; non-tPA: q1h x 24h, then q4h

monitoring.action: Acetaminophen; cooling measures; infection workup if >38°C
Supplemental O2; if <90% consider intubation for large strokes
Declining LOC: STAT CT, ICP management

monitoring.frequency: Daily until stable, then per protocol
q24-48h if contrast given or on new medications
Fasting within 24-48h; repeat at 4-12 weeks on statin
monitoring.action: Intensify statin; add ezetimibe or PCSK9i

disposition.criteria: Minor stroke (NIHSS 0-3) with stable exam, adequate support at home, able to perform ADLs or with home health, completed workup or reliable outpatient follow-up arranged, medications filled
Moderate stroke (NIHSS 4-15), requires IV medications or ongoing monitoring, incomplete workup, dysphagia requiring NPO/modified diet, new atrial fibrillation requiring anticoagulation initiation

Post-tPA monitoring (first 24h), post-thrombectomy, large territory infarct with edema risk, posterior fossa stroke with herniation risk, unstable BP requiring IV antihypertensives, declining neurologic exam, respiratory compromise

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: LVO needing thrombectomy (transfer to comprehensive stroke center), need for neurosurgical intervention not available, need for neuro-ICU not available
Moderate-severe deficits (NIHSS >4), able to participate in 3h/day therapy, expected to benefit from intensive rehab, medically stable
Unable to tolerate 3h/day rehab, needs skilled nursing care, medically complex requiring ongoing monitoring
Mild deficits, safe home environment, reliable follow-up, family support available
